Martin, this is a wonderful puzzle.  Zantac was my first acid preventer.  I’ve now progressed to Nexium.  The wife wore her UGG boots on our recent Maine trip and was so upset with the stains the melted ice left.  I wore my LL Beans duckshoes and they were perfect. The private Life Insurance company I work for is making its sick policy less comfortable for its employees. Its especially hard for individuals like myself who suffer from a seizure disorder. I consider myself "upper middle class" and feel like I have no one representing people in my shoes. The workers at our apartment building, though they aren't making big bucks, their benefits are quite good with pension, healthcare and vacation.

If our new mayor wants to be a big hit, he should ne spending his time improving the city's infrastructure (subways) and empower people with knowledge and education so companies don't hire as many educated foreigners from places like India.

Pandering and slogans and symbolism will get us nowhere fast.

RJD,  I see that many readers recommended your comment. The fact is it is only 5 days and not 10 or 15 days. Maybe, in certain circumstances, it should be more but it isn't and won't be. The ACA has nothing to do with this. It will wither away but, for now, requires more than 50 employees not mom and pop shop numbers. And larger small businesses can opt on by paying a fine. You are correct about mom and pop shops in NYC being forced out of business by high rents (and huge chains as well i.e. The A and P)  but controlling high rents, high taxes, increasing consumer demand are not merely NYC issues but national ones. The President has succeeded in providing hope but not change and de Blasio has provided hope and will likely produce little change with big time fan-fare. Don't expect to see "one city" in your lifetime which I hope is long.
I think a $15 NYC minimum wage bill has been proposed.

Why only 5? How about 10 or 15 days? Can a $15 minimum wage be far behind? And let's not forget the ACA. I walk the streets of the City and over the course of the last 5 years I've see more and more mom & pop stores closing up shop. These stores are being forced out due to enormous taxes, high rents, lower consumer demand, and now increasing labor costs. These stores are being replaced by a bevy of large chains, banks, drug, and mobile phone stores on every block. The uniqueness and distinctiveness of the City is being wiped out as the cost of doing business for the "little guy" is out of control. And all of this was before the tale of two cities was officially launched. It is going to be interesting to see what's left after the next 4 years unfold. For every action there is a reaction.

Alan:  Congratulations. I see a lot of readers have recommended your comments as well. Most of the time, my comments don't get highly recommended because they are usually contrary to the prevailing viewpoint of most of the readers of the NT Times.  However, my comments usually offer the readers an alternative opinion based on reality and not purely emotion.  The truth is that we would all love to see a City where everyone lives happily ever after.  Unfortunately, sometimes government policies that attempt to force a certain outcome might just incur the opposite effect. It is rather easy to ride a wave of populism by taking from some to give to others ....sounds great. But invariably it's the hardworking folks in the middle & not the 1% that are required to foot the bill. Hence, they will react in the only way possible.....when the numbers don't add up...they will just close up shop and join the growing ranks of the unemployed.  An outgoing tide lowers all boats.

Paid sick leave. A total of 5 days! If this is liberalism and a left turn the entire city should be for it, including the 1%. It is certainly only symbolic and does not make us one city. When I stop seeing homeless on the streets and gleaming new condo construction for the affluent, and new restaurants opening for the super rich, knick tickets that are affordable, a living wage rather than a one dollar increase in the minimum wage, maintaining hospitals in all sectors of the city, not just urgent care centers replacing them and reform of the drug laws I'll believe we are making genuine progress, not before.
Great idea. Your grateful employees will remember your punitive policy when you go on vacation. Enjoy yourself when you are away.

As a small business owner, I offer three weeks of paid vacation a year.  Now it will be two come April and they will need a doctors note.  This is how most businesses that offer paid vacation will do it.  It will probably change things much more for  those businesses that do not offer paid vacation time.

Are you suggesting that everyone with a 24 hour bug must see a doctor? Do you? If you see a doctor every time you get a twinge then you are the reason why the costs of health insurance are so high. People and family members often get sick for a day or two. This proposal says that an employer must provide five days of paid sick time per year. An employer who already provides  5 paid sick days or more won't be effected by the law. An employer who provides 3 sick days per year will only have to provide 2 sick days.

Making everyone get a doctors note every time they are will will further needlessly stress the medical system, raising costs further (yes, someone always pays at some point, whether the individual or the taxpayer), and making already crowded doctors' offices and ER's even more jammed just to please the paperwork requirement.

Since health insurance is required, now, for everyone, there is no excuse for a sick person to not see a doctor.

Make those who call in sick get a doctors note to prove they are, really, sick. Same for someone they are caring for.

The Federal government requires people out for longer than three days on sick leave to do it, no reason businesses can make their employees do the same.

The real question is how are they going to enforce it.  Will small business respond by firing US citizen workers and replacing them with undocumented immigrants who are afraid of going to the authorities?  Next up, how about a minimum wage that is tied to what the boss makes?  For example, if your boss is the CEO of UnitedHealth Group, who in 2009 was paid over a hundred million dollars in compensation, then your minimum wage ought to be say, $40,000/year.  But if you work for someone who himself is just getting by, then $15/hour would be more reasonable.

Why are there Republicans?

Again SB..you would be right if the new mayor did what Wagner and Lindsey did...ie...turn NYC into a welfare state.

This is a reasonable move that puts us in the 21 century with the rest of the civilized world.

People abuse motherhood and apple pie. It doesn't mean we should not have them.

This is an old story. Some never learn.

Ask not what you can do for your city, ask what your city can do for you?
This proposal provides for five paid sick days per year. How does it amount to giving people "more days off"? Are you suggesting that 5 days off per year is too much?

I'm sorry that you don't understand that part of the gap between the ultra-rich and the rest of us, especially the poor, is our health.  For example, those with money to burn are living longer while the lifespan for the poor is going down.   Everyone gets sick, rich or poor, everyone has a right to medical care and the time off work to get well.   Or, do you prefer encouraging epidemics llike we had in 1918?

It means when you are sick and have to still come to work because you can't afford not to, versus being able to stay home and get well. I would say that is something pretty basic that the rich get, but low-paid workers don't. Eliminating that is definitely a small step in narrowing the gap.

So his goal is to narrow the gap between rich and poor?
So how does giving low-paid workers more days off do that, exactly?

During the Great Depression, my grandfather, who had a Ford Dealership near Bridgehampton on Long Island, continued to pay his employees even though business was lousy.  That Ford Dealership is still there, though my grandfather died in 1934.  Lots of businesses did the same.  People enlisted in the Great War back then because it was the right thing to do, not just because it was convenient or friendly to small business owners.  And when the soldiers came back, they gave them jobs.  They valued their employees and their employees were loyal to them.  Passing the nickel onto the consumer won't break the bank and the impact on morale might, not surprisingly, enhance productivity.  American businesses have gotten very comfortable with their greed over the last few decades.  Luxembourg, by the way, has the highest minimum wage in the EU.

It is not quite as easy as you would like. Several good computer security companies are working to stop spam, but several countries will not cooperate. China, Brazil and some Eastern European countries, and of course Nigeria.

There is a huge network of infected computers known as netbots, that are controlled by other netbots. there are companies that track and document these spammers, and provide the information to ISPs and government agencies for blocking. You can go to Spamhaus.org to see one effort, but the other problem is many major providers refuse to block large blocks of IP numbers. The backbone operators such as AT&$, will not block a whole country such as China, even though they are a major source of spam.

The whole system depends on the root servers that also would have to be configured to block these sources, and that would probably bring the internet to a halt.

So in many cases, the spammers are well known, but they can not be stopped by any authorities. Another reason is the Direct Mailing Association that prevented laws allowing you to sue spammers. They got the Can Spam Law also known as the You can spam law, when states had legislation to allow suing spammers. So you have to opt out when you get spam, instead of telling companies it is OK, you have to wait until you are spammed by a member of the DMA before you can tell then no.

Again, look who gets their way, and it is not you.

It's a great question why the NSA's surveillance apparatus ins't apaprently used much to target this kind of banking fraud. There's any number of "national security" justifications for safeguarding our payments systems, criminal activity has long been used to fund terrorism, and the shadowy nexus of Russian intelligence and organized crime is pretty well known.

It remains baffling to me that the NSA is apprently doing nothing about this while focusing so many resources on domestic surveillance of its own citizens. We can put software to burn out centerfuges in the underground bunkers used by the Iranian nuclear program but we can't do anything about large-scale electronic fraud? I just don't buy it, epsecially considering that the NSA has long focused on electronic surveillance of Russia in particular, which appears to be the "home base" of so much of this kind of thing.

So the NSA seems to be snooping everywhere ... in the name of combating terrorism.

If Target can be targeted (sorry), how about Healthcare.Gov or Senate.Gov or WhoKnowsWhat.Mil?

Now, I know that NSA is tight-lipped, but they DO like to say that all their snooping IS stopping terrorism in its tracks. The silence is deafening! Can we fire them? Or - at the very least - can't they rid the Internet of spam?
